awd_titl_txt: CRII: CHS: Making Universally Usable Technologies to Enhance Parent-Child Co-Reading and Early Literacy Skills at Home
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study how technology can better support early literacy skills for children. Research has shown that children can learn important skills when parents read with them at home, but children from low income families or families where one parent has a disability often enter kindergarten far behind their peers. To give these children more equal access to literacy, this study will work with blind parents from low-income families to create new reading technologies for use with children. This research is important because one in seven Americans has "below basic" literacy skills, a fact which threatens our national security and economic prosperity.  

This project will study parent-child co-reading experiences with a focus on enhancing "extra-textual" interactions, as when a father asks his child a question about a storybook plot and the child responds by pointing to pictures on the page. Interactive technology presents new opportunities to scaffold these important extra-textual interactions towards achieving "reading readiness" for all children. Taking a participatory, universal usability approach to design, solutions will be developed primarily with and for blind parents who co-read with their sighted children.  Follow-up investigations will probe the potential for these solutions to extend benefits to broader populations. Project outcomes will include an inclusive phenomenological model of co-reading, and a technology prototype for domestic settings..

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over one million people in the United States of America are blind. Some people are born blind, others develop blindness in adolescence or early adulthood, and others acquire it later in life as they age. Despite the popular misconception that blind people are not independent, many strategies and digital tools exist to enable blind people to have equal access to activities like reading printed or digital text. For example, on a computer, a blind person can read a news article on the web by using a screen reader, which is controlled with the keyboard and can read the text aloud with a computerized voice. Even printed text, like the text on a restaurant menu, can be read aloud when a blind person holds their camera phone up to the page using a special app. But, how well do these reading technologies work when blind parents read with their young children? Consider that many parents read to their children at night, when the lights are turned down low and the iphone camera apps are less reliable. Or, the parent may be holding their child and have difficulty using their keyboard and laptop to read at the same time. This research project set out to learn more about how blind parents currently read with their children and whether there are any promising technologies for making reading more accessible.

The first study we ran looked at what blind parents said in an online discussion forum about reading to their children. We learned that blind parents have a variety of ways they can read with their child. For example, some parents listen to audiobooks or YouTube videos of other parents reading to their children, then they memorize and recite the book to their child, sometimes as the child holds the print book in their lap. Few blind parents have been taught to read Braille, but many expressed an interest in learning. Given that voice assistants are popular among blind adults, we began to develop a novel reading technology idea that uses a voice assistant to help blind parents practice Braille reading while preparing to recite books to their children. To better understand the potential of this technology, we ran another study with blind parents who own voice assistants. The second study found that blind parents tended to use the voice assistant often and wanted their voice assistant to do more for them; this is because voice assistants can easily be spoken to, without having to use complicated screen readers. Finally, we ran a third study, which looked at past research papers to see if blind parents and their needs are being attended to. We found that very few research papers consider the roles that blind people occupy as caregivers, like parents, and therefore there are not enough technologies designed for their caregiving needs. As a result of these three studies, more attention is being paid to blind people who have children and how to design reading technologies for them.
